MY MOTHER'S GRAVE.
SUNG DY MR. JOHN KELLY.
Where the valley brook is slowly creeping,
And the wood bird sings its lonely song,
Where the willow boughs are sadly weeping,
Where the sephyrs murmuring pass along
There my gentle mother's form reposes,
Dearly loved in chilehood's happy day.
At the gajve I kneel 'mid clustering r^sos,
Weeping twilight's stilly hour away.
Can I 'mid the toils of life forget thee,
Angel guardian of my infant years 1
Every care compels me to regret thee,
Every smile is chased away by tears.
Holy precepts by thy lips were given,
How I've kept them let my anguish own,
Dearest mother, from thy home iu heaven,
Lean down and listen to my anguished moan.
TELEGRAPHIC*
A letter is published from Sherman on
board a gunboat in Ossabaw Sound, Dec. 13.
He states that Gen. Haven's division assault*
ed Fort McAllister on the 15th, and carried
it, capturiug the garrison and stores. This
opened the channel to the Sound, by which
be communicated with the fleet. All the
railroads leading into Savannah are destroy
ed, and the city invested. The left is on the
Savannah River, 15 miles above the city, and
the right on the Ogeechee, at King's Bridge,
Supplies are abuudant and the army in good
condition. Two boats were captured on the
Savannah RiVer, preventing the rebel
gunboats from coming down. The estimated
m
population of Savannah is 25,000 : garrison,
15,000. Hardee is in command. He says he
"destroyed over 200 miles of railroad, and
many stores essential to Lee and Hood. He
concludes by saying, *' 1 regard Savannah as
already gained."
The Herald's correspondent says Sherman's
entire loss from Atlanta to Savannah was
about 1000—traveled about 12 miles per day.
The fight around Nashville is still going
on. It is reported that Wood is in Hood's
rear, and that the rebel forces at Franklin
were retreating ; also rumored that Forrest
' was routed at Murfreesboro on the 15tb.
Richmond papers say Foster's raid on the
SaTannuh railroad was a failure, and that
Savannah is not invested. A proposition is
made in Congress to tax all sales one per ct.,
which meets with favor. Copies of orders
</t Breckinridge are published, ordering his
men to husband small arms, ammunition and
lead. A call and draft for 300,000 more
troops has been made by the President . m Bur
bridge had a fight with Basil Duke's brigade,
formerly John Morgan's, in Tennessee, routing
him and killing Dick Morgan, John Morgan's
brother. A rebel rumor says Hood is to be
reinfprced by Price, Breckinridge and Ma
gruder. Forrest is near the Hermitage. Hood
has fallen back from Nashville, and Thomas
is pressing him. Wilmington is supposed to
be the point aimed at by tbe great expedition
from Hampton Roads. A letter from Lord
Russell says the British Government will
continue strictly neutral. Dayton, American
Minister at Paris, is dead. Semraes is on tbe
Sea King, whose name is changed to Shenan
doah. The vessel is heavily armed, and 1000
tons register and very fast.
The Yreka Journal of December 9tb,—
«ays it rained and snowed for the
three weeks previous, and the country has
been under a flood, causing a great deal of
damage. Scott river was difficult to cross ;
Humbug creek was a river, and Yreke creek
was "booming; Shasta Valley was flooded,
bat the bridge escaped destruction.
Col. Sam Mkuabt, one of Ohio's most no
ble sons, and long tbe editor of the Ohio
Crisis, died at bis home, one day before the
Presidential election.
CANYON CITY PAPER-*.
BY XINN1R MYRTLE.
CHILL NOVEMBER.
" Oh," says the owl, " my head's so white !
What shall I do this live-long night?"
Some " dull corner" of roy head has been
keeping time to this little refrain all the eve
ning and all the while I've been thinking
4 how glad I am not an owl 1 '
It is a very stormy night. How the wind
sweeps down the narrow Cnfion ! bow madly
it besieges our little homes that we have
builded here for tbe sake of jobbing these
barren old hills of their sepulchered god of
men and women. The weather has been very
much akin to a Webfoot winter for the past
few days. All day the streets have been
sloppy and the men hurrying along distress
edly, dripping and grumbling about the rain.
To-night it is dolefully doleful.
*• Heart-broken moans the homeless mind
As if the whole world was unkind."
November is truly a month of sobrietiePj
of melancholy reveries of gentle memories,
of half regretful recollections ; it i3 not meet
for giddy fancies, for joyous hopes or gay air
palaces.
When the winds and the rain are weeping
over us, we too bow our beads and bewail—
not bitterly, but with a kind of satisfaction—
over our broken hopes and weep with the
November rain that the Summer blooms have
faded. We say no more the high and hope
ful things that once we said, but witb subdued
spirits we look back as if through blinding
rain to tbe misty scenes of the Past and
whisper—" it might bave been."
Yes, "it might have been." It might bave
been always Summer, tbe bright flowers
might, never have faded, nor the gay leaves
perished. Fair brows might forever be fair,
and " golden hair stay golden ; " dancing
feet might never lose their fleetness, norring
ing voices their music ; buoyant youth might
uever collapse into old age,—nor hopeful
hearts, once warm and quick witb love and
joy, become tbe'borne of dull remorse and
chill-corroding care.
Sitting here to-night listening to the storm
and somewhat blues-oppressed, l feel like
doing a little wailing myself :
MY WAIL.
The shadows are crouching and filling the room,
Without the wild wind blows ;
Aud I sit here in the silence and gloom—
This is the life I chose.
All day long while the chill rains fall,
I sit in my chamber and write, 4
And then with the darkness that covers all,
Come thronging the shadows at night.
I write of lovo and of broken hearts,
Of a rest that will come at last,
And smile to think of one I knew,
Away in the shining past.
»
•To think how over his youthful face
The death-white palor came,
When I told him that night in my gauze and lace,
I had bartered my Love for Fame. •
There are voices away in the Long Ago,
That could banish the shadows and pain.
But tbe Past is laid in a sepulchre low—«
It never will come again.
Leave, cold shadows, my silent room,
Creep back from my empty heart;
Let the past be hid in the silent tomb,
Let the spectral shadow depart.
44 Deeply, darkly, beautifully blue,"
This is the life I chose,
Sitting here in the silence and gloom—
Where is the "colour de rose ?"
There, I, have wailed my wail I Now for
something else.
THE MINES.
All flimsy fancies and idle poetical dream
ing must give way at times to something
practical and bard. I know of no subject
more practical than making money, and gold
is hard—bard to get, and hard to keep.
The mines in this place, I believe, average
very well. Some pay big, and some bigger;
some pay little, and some less—and some not
at ail. This is the information I elicited from
a friend of mine. I cannot speak from prac
tical knowledge, not being a miner myself.
A very good looking miner came in the
other evening with his gold pan, and said he
wanted to show me how much be had taken
from his claim that day. I think there was
about a quart of tbe ponderous metal iu the
pan. I offered to introduce him to a nice
Immigrant girl, but he did not seem to think
much of it.
CANYON CITY.
Caüon City may be destined to become a
great city, and it may not. At any rate it is
improving quite rapidly, and some very stylish
little houses are being erected. The Catholic
Church is now completed. It is a neat ouild
ing for a mining camp, and stands away up
un the hill overlooking the town like a guar
dian angel.
• But for fear of trespassing on the columns
of your pretty little paper, I will bring my
letter to a close.
By the way, we polled quite a nice little
majority for McClellan here—or rather our
meo did, us "females" of course having
nothing to do with it—but alas 1 it did no
good.

GROWING OLD.
T ley sit together at the door,
Through which, long years ago,
They passed, a newly-wedded pair,
Iu yout h's first rosy glow.
Then her round cheek was red and warm,
' Her hair wa3 rippling gold ;
Ilis form was stately as the oak—
But now they both are old.
The blooming cheek is wrinkled now,
The sweet blue eyes are dim;
But, full of love and holy trust,
They ever turn to him,
With the calm faith and hope she felt
Upon her bridal day,
When the long future, flower-clad,
Stretched out before her lay.
Now, in the eventide of life,
They watch the purple haze
Grow on the hills, and hang aboVe
The laud-locked chain of bays ;
They see the sun sink slowly down
To gladden other lamb ;
They feel night coining, and they sit
Serene, with close-cla3ped hands.
They know that though the dusk is here
There is a place of light,
Invaded not by gloom or shade,
Or the drear, weeping night.
They wait with patience for the call,
To tread the darksome vale,
Unto the hights, before whose glow
The morning sim would pale.
AN ACT
Relating to the Discovery of Gold and Silver
Quartz Leads,and the Manner of their Loca
tion.
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislative
Assembly of the Territory of Idaho, a3 fol
lows*— That any person or persons who may
hereafter discover any quartz lead or lode,
shall be entitled to oue claim thereon by right
of discovery, and one claim each, by location.
I 2. That a quartz claim shall consist of
two hundred feet in length along the lead or
lode, by two hundred feet in width, covering
and including all dips, spurs and angles with
in the bounds of said claim, as also the right
of drainage, tunneling, and such other privi
leges as may be necessary to the working of
said claim ; provided, that nothing in this Act
shall be construed as to give any claimant or
claimants, auy right to any separate or dis
tinct ledge, other than the oue claimed run
ning through the said two hundred feet in
width or to obstruct any subsequent claimant
in working and improving such distinct ledge,
and the center of the ground between such
ledges shall be the dividing line between the
respective claimants.
\ 2. The locater of any quartz claim, or
claims' on any lead or lode, shall at the time
of locating said claim or claims, place a sub
stantial stake, not less than three inches in
diameter, at each end of said claim or claims,
on which shall be a written notice specifying
the name of the locator, the number of feet
claimed, together with the day, month and
year, when the same was taken.
\ 4. Two or more persons may locate or
take claims together in a body, by joining in
a notice, specifying the number of claims
located, and the name of each person joining
in such uotice being written under the notice
—but the claims so taken shall not exceed
two hundred feet for each individual joining
in such notice, except when necessary to In
clude a discovery claim. Persons so joining
in one notice shall be considered as tenants
in common, and the work hereinafter required
to be performed on a quartz claim, to entitle
the locator or his assigns to hold the same as
real estate, may be performed on any one or
the claims so held in common ; provided, it
be equal in amount to one hundred dollars
fir each claim held in common, including the
discovery claim.
\ 5. All claims shall be recorded in the
County Recorder's office within ten days from
the time of posting notice thereon ; provided
that when the claim located is more than
thirty miles from the couuty seat, the time
shall extend to fifteen days ; provided, further,
that no person shall record in the name of
any other person, unless he have the written
authority of such person or persons, and ex
hibit the same to the Recorder, and make an
affidavit, to be taken by such Recorder, that
the written authority is genuine : who shall
make a minute of such authority on his rec
ords, and file such affidavit in his office.
g 6. Quartz claims recorded in accordance
with the provisions of this Act, shall entitle
the person or persons so recording , to hold
the same' t<gjbe use of himself, his heirs and
assigns ; provided, that within six months
from and after the date of recording, he or
they shall perform, or cause to be performed
thereon, work amounting in value to^one
hundred dollars tor each claim of two hund
red feet.
\ 7. Any person or persons holding quartz
claims in pursuance of the provisions of this
Act, shall renew the notice required in sec
tions three and four of this Act, at least
once in twelve months, and perform fifty dol
lars worth of work annually, for such claim
so located and held.
\ 8. Any person or persons desiring to
preserve and perpetuate testimony as to the
sufficiency of the amount of work done on
any claim or claims, to entitle him or them to
hold them as real estate, according to the
provisions of section six of this Act, may
take two disinterested persons to view such
work, who shall carefully examine the same ;
immediately after which tfiey shall go before
the County Recorder, or some magistrate in
the county, and take (and) subscribe an affi
davit containing: First, a description of the
location of the claim or claims on which the
work is performed, the character and value
of such work, and the date when they re
viewed the same, which affidavit shall be filed
by the Couuty Recorder, and carefully pre
served. Such affidavits or certified copies of
the same, under the certificate and seal of the
County Recorder, who has the custody of the
original affidavit or affidavits, shall, in any
court in this Territory, be prima lacia evi
dence of the character and the amount of
labor performed on the claim or claims which
are described in such aflidavitor affidavits.
\ 9. Conveyances of quartz claims shall
require the same formalities, and shall be
subject to tbe same rules of construction as
the transfer and conveyance of real estate.
\ JO. All claims heretofore taken up or
located jointly, in a manner similar to that
now permitted by section four of thi3 Act
shall be considered, and the same are hereby
maee, valid and sufficient in law.
\ 11. All tunnels which may be run into
any hill or mountain, for the purpose of dis
covering and working mineral-bearing quartz
lodes, commonlv termed " blind lodes," shall
be entitled to hold five hundred feet each way
from the line of tunnel on said lode or lodes
so discovered. They shall also be entitled to
one thousand feet square at the entrance, or
entrances, ot said tunnel, or tunnels, for
building, dumping, or other purposes deemed
necessary. The manner of locating such
tunnel rights shall be the same as prescribed
for the location of quartz claims, in this Act,
an 1 shall be held in accordance with the pre
visions of section six of this Act, except that
the amount of work to be performed sha 1 be
five hundred dollars ; and in case of failure
to comply with such provisions, the right or
claim shall be considered vacated, and shall
not be re-located by the same parties. Noth
ing in this section shall be so construed as to
give any tunnel company the right to work
any lode discovered and located by other
parties prior to their discovering the same,
uirless such claims are forieited from non
compliance with the law.
§ 12. That the Act entitled "An Act re
lating to the discovery of gold and silver
quartz leads, and of the manner of their lo
cation," approved February,4th, 1864, be and
tbe same is hereby repealed.
$ 13. This Act to takg effect on and after
its approval by the Governor.

A Conquest without Laurels.-Not should
these Abolitionists flatter themselves that, if
they can succeed in their object of uniting
the people of the free States, they will enter
the contest with numerical superiority that
must insure victory. All history and experi
ence proves the hazard and uncertainty of
war. And we are admonished by holy Writ
ihat the race is not to tbe swift nor the battle
to tbe strong. But if they were to conquer,
whom would they conquer? A foreign foe,
one who had insulted our flag, invaded our
shores and laid our country waste? No, sir;
no, sir. It would be a conquest without lau
rels, without glory—a self, a suicidal con
quest—a conquest of brothers over brothers,
achieved by one over another portion of the
descendants of common ancestors who, nobly
pledging their fortunes and their sacred hon
or, had fought and bled, side by side, in many
a hard battle on laud and ocean, severed our
country from the British crown, and estab
lished our national independence.—[Henry
Clay's Speech.

A WIFE WITH A WOODEN LEG.
She's pretty and young, and tender and true,
And I know that her temper is good,
But there's a trifliug defect, J whisper it to you,
'Tis a very fine leg made of wood.
Now some they may think perchance 'tis a grief,
This lo 38 of my fond little spouse,
Yet quite the reverse, 'tis a constant relief
To have such a thing in one's house.
She never can stamp or kick in her rage,
Or in wrath from our houso will she run,
For in stealing her leg/1 thus can assuage
The stom till its raging is done.
No running or gadding can give her delight,
She sits up till her eyes are dim, .
And cannot bo dancing with fçols all the night,
With that awkward thing of a limb.
8he wears out few shoes or stockings, I find, >
On that well shaped dummy of wood;
A saving of cash that is quite to my mind,
I buy them so cheap when they're odd.
1
ife, with her dear wooden leg,
„er one leg I love all the more,
And nover would wish for two in it* stead—
One's enough if wo think the thing o'er.

of the rebels ; of their having " robbed the
cradle and the grave;" of the absolute ne
cessity of their yielding from having already
put in the field the last available man, that
many persons too ready to accept as truth,
the plausible assertion, really believe that
such a^ condition of things exists. The
Washington correspondent ot the Portland
(Maine) Advertiser, gives the following facts
showing what is the remaining strength of
the white forces of the Confederacy, and how
very far removed the Southern people are
from exhaustion :
" Not one-third of the able-bodied white
men of the South have as yet entered the
army. The South bad 1,000,000 white men
-of the proper military age, when the war be
gin, and 200,000 boys who bave since attain
ed to that age, making 1,800,000 men. The
States have furnished up to this time, in all
850,000 men, of whom 558,000 have perished
in battle, or by disease. 60,000 are now
prisoners in our bands, 20,000 are iu bospi
tala, slightly wounded, and 212,000 constitute
the Confederate armies now in the field. They
have yet 550,000 white men, from which to
keep their armies full, and they do not there
fore need -the negroes as soldiers."
Those who boast that the war is near an
•ending, will do well to study these figures.—
Add to this the vast number of able-bodied
negroes who can and will be summoned to the
field, when they deem it politic or necessary
and the greatness of the work of conquest
and subjugation yet before the Administra
tion is made fully apparent. The war as
prosecuted by the party in power, is only in
its infancy. The work of " crushing out the
rebellion," is to be an unending one if noth
ing but brute force is to be employed.

" War-Time Excesses," writes N. P. Willi» '
in the N. Y. Home Journal, " have substituted
altogether a new ferocity for the long accus
tom .-u money-making sagacity in the charac
ter of our countrymen. He illustrates our
rampant Americanism by a quotation from
the book of Judges. It is there told, as a final
________ „ .
tfifect of Israel's war with the Pbillistines,—
that, "lo llio.e days there was no King in
did that which
Israel, but every man
right in his own eyes."
Than which, continues he, " ft more faith
ful picture of the men seen in Broadway and
the Bowery, at the present moment, could
not possibly be written." Mr. Willis then
proceeds in his observations: "Yet the
briakiag out of this pustule of corrupt mat- I
ter on the face of our feverish nation— 1 " 15
one-man insolence— Î3 seen no more under
the military outton than under the rags of |
the beggar. Notwithstanding the prodigious
multiplication of beggars, there is no longer I
any humiity in their behavior. Be it a sold
ier or an old woman, a child, or a cripple, I
the needed ch.rity is iu.oleotly ^
sulkily or saucily—and the boon 13 given,
taken as a right, and without thanks ; or, it
refused, correspondingly resented. Nor can
we contemplate with satisfaction the change
which we actually see, in the visage of our
young men, as made by war. There is here
and there a noble looking fellow among them
it is true; but the most ot tne men, now met
in Broadway and the Bowery, (the hundreds
of these same "heroes at home on leave,")
are saucily wirlike. And it is not seen
merely in the twirling of a moustache or the
defying of an eye; but who that bas an oc
casion to ride in a car, or mingle, as a stran
ger, now-a-days, in a crowd of our great city,
can be pleased with the new manners which
do certainly prevail—the shouldering and
elbowing, the rough jostling and rude lan
guage, the indifference, sulky and savage of
every man to his neighbor, ar.d the complete
un-deferential conduct of every gathering
everywhere, it for their own independent
pleasure—of men, women and children ? And
1 for a lesser result) it has positively made
more discordant the common key of the pop
ular voice ; while we think that the unseen
working of the same fierce spirit is actually
changing, for the worse, our prevailing na
tional type of female beauty !

New York Election.— The canvass of the
vote of the State of New York for President
of the United States in the recent election
was concluded at Albany daring the week,
by the State canvassers. The whole number
of votes cast was seven hundred and thirty
thousand seven hundred and twelve, of which
three hundred aud sixty-eight thousand sev
en hundred and twentj-six were given for the
Lincoln and Johnson electors, and three
hundred and sixty-one thousand nine hun
dred and eighty-six for the McClellan and
Pendleton. The Republican majority is
therefore six thousand seven hundred and
forty. Mr. Greeley, one of the Republican
electors at large, received two hundred and
thirty-five votes less than his colleague, Mr.
Preston King. Between the numbers re
ceived by each of the Democratic electors at
large there was a variance of but five votes,
Mr. Washington Hunt receiving that many
more than Mr. Wm. Kelly.—[New York Pa
per, Dec. 10.
Important Decision. —In the case of Pedro
Casttllo against the Pacific Mail Steamship
Company, for $25,600 damages for insufficient
accommodations as a passenger, and the loss
of $6,500 in treasure on the Golden Gate,
the case ineolcing the entire qneation of the j
liability of the Company for losses on the
steamer, the Court rendered a verdict for the
defendants on the ground that the Company
was not liable in cases of the total loss of |
a vessel and cargo, and that the receipt did
not set forth the exact character, amount and j
value of the package so lost.

SCALDSANDBURNS.-Dr. Hall says the best,
most instantaneous and most accessible rem
edy in the world, is to thrust the injured part
in cold water, send for a physician and while
he i9 coming, cover the part an inch or more
deep with common flour. The water gives j
instantaneous relief, by excluding the oxygen
of the air ; the flour does the same thing, bat
is preferable because it can be kept more con- j
tinuonsly applied with less inconvenience!
than by keeping the part under water.

with a kind of look iu bis face that reminds I

THE MEETING OF THE WATERS.
Close beside the meeting waters
Long I stood as in a dream,
Watching how tbe little river
Fell into the broader stream.
Calm and still the mingled current ,
Glided to the waiting sea;
On its breast serenely pictured
Floating cloud and skirting tree.
And I thought, "Oh, human spirit 1
Strong and deep and pure and blest,
Let the stream of iny existence
Blend with thiue, and find its rest 1 "
I could die as dies the river
Iu the current deep and wide ;
I would live as live the waters,
Flashing from a stronger tide!

Mac A rone and the Deserter.
The amusing war correspondent of the N.
Y. Leader, writing " from the front," on the
Potomac, or James, says :
A little further on l came to a reliable de
serter, who lay on a sand heap scratching
himself. These deserters are very nice fel
lows.
As I approached he rose and saluted.
"Jes'came f'm 'tuther side, gin'ral," says
he.
"What do you want," says I.
" I'm powerful dry," says he.
I called an orderly and bade him fetch some
whisky.
" Now," says I, 11 how's things overon your
side ? "
" Well," says he, "pretty bad. Old Lee,
he ain't got no men whatsomever."
" I guess you lie," says I. " We felt his
line the other day, and it didn't feel good.
You might just as well tell the truth."
" Oh 1 " says be, I was only speaking figu
ratively like. He ain't got no men to speak
of—fifty or sixty hundred thousand, mebbe."
" H'm, that's enough," says I.
"Yes, only they ain't good for nothing.
They ain't got no ammunition."
" Tney keep up a devil of a firing," says I,
" for men without ammunition."
" Wal, yes,*' says he, " that's what's run
the blockade. Thar's a
tiou runs the blockade."
" Short of rations ? " says I.
" Dreadf l short," says he. " We don't get
only a cracker every three days." .
II Why, I killed a lot of you up yonder
while ago with their knapsacks full."
" 0, yes. That's wh&t they got f m the
Shandoah Walley. They got a heap of food
up yonder. Fact, they h^s all they want to
oat, jes now."
" You're bound to suit, arn't you," says I.
" How are you off for ordnance?"
" 0, our ordnance is orf'l," says he.
"Yes," says I, "Is'pose so. But, young
naan, I've got an ordnance, too, about offal,
and I keep it pretty well cleared out of these
lines. Now you'd better clear out. I go in
for treating my fellow men well, but when it
comes to rebels, and lying deserters, and ly
ing deserters at that, I can't say I see it.
What do you expect to do round here?"
" VV^ell," says he, " I kinder thort I'd go
North and play Union refugee. I'm told it
pays fust rate at Lincoln meetin's."
" And how are you going to get to the
North ?" »
" I s'pect you'll send me."
" Do you ?"
"Yes ; if you don't, I'll jes' go back again
to old Lee, and tell him all I seen in your
lines."
This is wha£ I call a good S^ecinlen of a
rebel. He went iu for dictating his own
terms. 1
I sent him np to headquarters and had him
hanged.
Old Abe's Last. —In dismissing & party of
three hungry office-seekers, who had often
wearied him, Mr. Lincoln reminded them of
tbe schoolmaster who told one his pupils to
read the third chapter of Daniel. The boy
began, but when he came tbe names of Shad
rach, Masheck and Abednego, he stumbed.
Tbe master told the boy he might read the
preceding chapter, and let the present one
go. He got on famously nntil he reached the
last verse, when, pausing, and casting a sav
age glance at the book, he exclaimed : "Well,
I'll be darned if here ain't them three fellers
again 1", f
•
r
^
The Abolition Successor of, Washington
^ Mr. Lincoln was at first, says the Patterson
(IL J.) Register, accidentally elected to the
Presidency of the United States, arid his lack
of statesmanlike qualities and the culture
and habits of a gentleman was not so direct
ly a disgrace to the people of this country as
if he had been fairly elevated to the "Chief
Magistracy by a fairly expressed majority.—
But the people cannot now escape the odium
of .having put a mere joker, an uncouth, un
cultivated fiatboatman, a buffoon, into the
seat which a Washington honored. The
majority of the people so voted, however, and
cannot avoid the disgrace. Now let every one
who gave bis ballot for "Abraham Lincoln
read the following {the truth of which is
vouched for by the World), and rejoice if
they can over the elevation of such a man as
Mr. Lincoln, whose classical conversation is
reported thus:
"How do you New York Democratic chaps
take my election?" asked Mr. Lincoln, a few
days ago, of a prominent New York McClel
lanite, with whom the Executive is pleased
to be on good personal terms. "Oh, pretty
Well, on'.he whole," was the reply. "Some
of Our boys complain, however, that you
carried the State by your postmasters steam
ing the envelopes that contained McClellan
and Seymour votes, thus opening the envel
opes and substituting Lincoln and Fenton for
McClellan and Seymour ballots." "Ha, ha,"
laughed the President, leaning forward and
grasping his ancles tightly; " so they say, do
they, that 1 came the 'gum game on them'
to be re-elected 1 Well, there's one comfort
about it, old fellow ; and this you can tell
them for me: that if I tried to cheat—
which they also did—by gum! I was success
ful, and they wern't !''
And that is the successor of George Wash
ington 1 i
A Noteworthy Fact. —An exchange very
truthfully remarks that you can always tell
from the advertising columns of a newspaper
who do the largest business and sell the
cheapest. The business man gifted with en
terprise and industry, having goods to sell,
will strive to outstrip his competitors, and
inform the public through the press what he
has for sale. This is so, and if our readers
wish to test the fact for themselves, let them
make a note on their next shopping tour of
the difference to be noticed between the es
tablishments of advertising and non-adver
tising firms. There will be found evidences
of thrift, indications of prosperity in the ad
vertising firm, a " snap" and wide awake air
about the employers and clerks, in striking
contrast with dull-, plodding ways of the " old
fogies," who don't " waste " money in adver
tising. If purchasers wish to know where
they will find the choicest goods and the
newest styles, they will carefully study the
advertising columns of their home paper,
The examination of drafted men in tbif
town closed on last week. Of the 211 men
drafted 1 was dead ; 2 were non-residents ; 62
were discharged on the ground of disability;
46 paid cdmmutationf 49 failed to appear;
3 were under age; 9 Were overage; 3 fur
nished substitutes' 14 were in the service;
and 16 are yet to pay or furnish substitutes.
Of the three substitutes, one is now in jail
charged with murder. So that but two men
out of the number drafted have found their
way into the army and they are Canadian
substitutes. One might fairly infer from
these facts that Old Abe's war for the nigger
is not very popular. " The people (îëmhnd
a vigorous prosecution of the war." Will
the "Loyal Leaguers" hereabouts point out
the "white feather party," against which they
prated so loudly, three years ago. We opine
the " peace party" is now the dominant one,
so far as numbers are concerned.—[Eastern
Paper.

Onr of the Spirit-Wrappers.— A man was
in the street the other night, who bad evi
dently taken in too much of the ardent for
convenient storage, and was rather unquietly
resting himself against a lamp-post, when an
acquaintance came aloDg, and observed that
tbe afflicted individual had on a new over
coat.
"Well, Bob," said he, "guess you have
been indulging in a new overcoat."
"Coat?" replied Bob, giving bis hat a
knock, and endeavoring to gesticnlate; " this
ain't a coat."
" Is n't a coat, eh ? Well, Bob, what is it,
then?"
Bcb elevated himself to a tottering pigpen
dicular, and exclaimed: "This 'ere ain't a
coat—it's a spirit-wrapper !"
Masonry. —Oh I who can tell the worth of
the Masonic Order? It follows tbe depraved
and desolate as long as hope remains ; it ad
ministers a balm to tbe wounded spirit ; cheers
up the happy to deeds of virtue, and to the
soul of the sorrowful whispers peace. Ma
sonry stands like an angel by the couch of
death, smooths tbe fevered pillow of the dy
ing, and as the lips of affection Huger in the
last long kiss, she whispers in tones of melt
ing tenderness a meeting beyond the grave 1
A young girl from Illinois went to St.
Louis, a few days ago, and sold herself for an
army substitute. When taken before the ex
aming surgeon, he ordered her to strip, but
this not exactly agreeing with her sense of
propriety, she ran out of the room and con
cluded lo give up soldiering until they would
take her word for being an able-bodied man.
"Do yon suppose that yon can do the
landlord in the 'Lady of Lyons?'" said a
manager to a seedy actor in quest of an en
gagement.
" I should thick I might," was the reply.
" I have done 1 a great many landlords.".

BETTER FROM LEWISTON.
Lewiston, January 2, 1865.
Editor World: As a reader of the first
Democratic journal published upon the soil
of Idaho, allow me to congratulate yon upon
the many evidences apparent of your success.
During the recent session of the Legislature,
I have looked in vain for some pen whose
facile movements should portray to their
constituents, through your columns, tbe
labors of their delegation, and their firm
adherence to the doctrines taught by Jefferson,
and the early founders of the Republic.
Legislators, like actors, need the approval of
the public, in order to crown their effort?
with final success.
LEGISLATIVE—A GOOD JOKE.
The first of the session passed smoothly
along, wlflT the exceptiaa or an occasional
ripple upon the surface the of political puddle,
near its close. Upon the introduction of the
^ Bounty bill, (framed in the ßanctum of his
Excellency, and, therefore, his pet,) party
lines were drawn, and woe be to the waver
ing. The mandate of his Highness had gone
forth, that the pretext for robbing the hardy
pioneers of Idaho should receive the sanction
of the Legislature ; that it might be legiti
mately done under statute law. The friends
of the bill were disinclined to give its pro
visions a very extensive airing,—choosing,
rather, to pass the matter through without
attracting much attention. At length it
became understood that, did they succeed
easily in the Council, the House was not
disposed to allow so gross an outrage upon
the people of this Territory to be perpetrated
with impunity. Although so modified as to
seem not wholly impracticable on its face,
still the tax levied under its provisions
solely for a "bunkum" record to lay before
Father Abraham—amounted to $45,000. The
first proposition called lor $144,000, which
was much nearer the actual amount needed.
Huge " bunkum " speeches from the Repub
licau members (who need re-election to keep
their seats) were made, lauding the Adminis
tration to the skies, and denouncing all who
refused to fall down and worship the image
that Caleb of " Lyonsdale " had set up, that
lor the want of a faithful reporter for your
journal, will be lost to their constituents
forever. Praise of worthy mefit is a delight
ful theme; when undeserved, however, it
becomes the most withering sarcasm. There
fore, in claiming tljat "we owe this to our
government at home, from the fact that she
has ever extended her protecting hand over
us,"—and this claim set up in tbe face of the
fact that, on the contrary, we have so far not
only paid all the usual taxes levied by our
government upon bid settled States,—but we
fbave also supported, at our o.wn expense, and
from an almost empty treasury, all the dis
reputable Federal officers sent here. Does
our government need these troops ? and what
for ? If we have to support (in addition to
the officers we have no voice in electing)
standing army, let the people have some voice
in the matter. Yoiir correspondent listened
attentively to the arguments,—or rather
"bunkum," of the Republicans in both
Houses, and it was also generally observed
that they left the merit of the bill untouched
Several good third rate Fourth-of-July ora
tions were had over it, and finally the funeral
6ermon was duly preached over it, and its
companion—the Militia bill, by the Reverend
member, in the House, from Idaho. Thus
10 xvv
foil as mad a scheme, and as destructive to
the best interests of the Territory, as ever
entered the brain of a fanatic.
The last day of the session at length came,
and with it a rather rich joke not wholly
without its lesson. During the passing of
party measures through the Council, of course
the Democracy were in the minority. This
enabled the Republicans to choke off discus
sion frequen'.ly, without authority of law, or
the rules of " Jefferson's Manual." Upon
several occasions this was done with impuni
ty, and the Chair, sustained by a majority, of
course, and at the expense of the minority.
However, an opportunity occurred for a little
sport, which had been concocted in the House,
by going into Joint Convention, and a reso
lution was passed through both Houses to
that effect.* Here was an opportunity to get
justice, as we would have a clear working
majority. A series of resolutions reviewing
the conduct of Federal officers, who had been
sent amongst us, were hastily drawn up, and
at an opportune moment offered by Mr. Fenn
of the Council, from Idaho. In a moment
the countenances of tbe Opposition members
changed from the self-satisfied smile of tri
umph won by them, for the last three weeks,
to the most blank look of surprise. The
reader can better imagine the ludicrous
spectacle presented if, in his schoolboy days,
he ha3 seen a large boy domineer, tyrannize
over, aad tantalize a smaller one before the
whole school until, by some unforeseen in
cident, he comes suddenly in contact with his
victim and finds himself completely in his
power. As might be expected from former
conduct, tbe " big boy " ran away. Thus it
proved with the Council majority—they
"bolted" from the house, disgracefully leav
ing the field, and refusing to accept an equal
show and a fair fight—saluted with shouts of
laughter from the lobby as they went. This
is Republican honor and sound Republican
inciple?.
THE CAPITAL, AND OTHER QUESTIONS.
The Capital question is becoming rather a
vexed one to everybody. Your correspondent
not being in the ring, can give but little infor
mation with regard to it. Blackstone seems
to have been consulted in the matter and, if
correctly interpreted by some of the ' Solons,'
I fear they will decide the last Assembly a
bogus body sure enough. This will sadly in
terfere with the operation of many healthy
laws passed during the last session.
The different applicants for tbe office of
Territorial Auditor and Territorial Treasurer,
will, also materially retard the business in
those offices. I havejust learned that Dr. M
A. Kelly, who was elected Territorial Treas
urer, has his bonds ready and will apply for
a certificate ; also, that Dr. E. Smith, appoin
ted by the Governor and Legislative Council
is preparing his;—meantime, writs y of in*
junction are being served on D. S. Kenyon
forbidding him deliverfng over to either any
books, records, or papers, belonging to said
office,—to which he also puts in a claim that
he was duly appointed to for the term pre
scribed by the statute, viz. : two years.
These numerous questions will hardly be
decided until near the expiration of the term
claimed by Kenyon. Thus the matter stands.
Pallas.
